Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Visualization, analysis, and HPC modeling of subglacial hydrology from high-resolution 3D conduit scans acquired with a novel sensor
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine the processes controlling the flow of water through and beneath an Arctic glacier. The hydraulic properties of glaciers are a major factor influencing the rate at which glaciers slide on the underlying rock. Understanding subglacial flow is critical to developing models that accurately predict how glaciers will behave in response to warming climate and how glaciers will contribute to sea level rise. For outreach and educational purposes, the project will develop a web-based, interactive fluid dynamics tutorial concerning subglacial conduits. A project web site will also be developed. The project will contribute to workforce development by supporting the training of a graduate student and by providing partial support for three early-career scientists.
This study will perform three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) large eddy simulations (LES) of turbulent flows in a subglacial conduit using realistic surfaces and mesh boundaries. The computations will be done using 3D high-performance computing. The conduit geometry and roughness will be based on a unique set of field measurements made on a Svalbard glacier using with a modified video-game controller at mm resolution. The result of this effort is a first-ever high resolution visualization of a real subglacial conduit and the first subglacial LES simulations with realistic geometry. Results will be compared with model output using the more standard Darcy-Weisbach or Manning formulations. The study will provide improved insights into hydrological processes in mountain glaciers and large ice sheets such as the Greenland Ice Sheet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The subglacial hydrodynamics beneath the Greenland ice sheet and associated ice dynamics are still the main source of uncertainties in predicting the meltwater production and global sea level rise. This uncertainty arises from the lack of data for the subglacial systems in Greenland ice sheet due to inaccessibility to this system. Therefore, computer models are often used to understand the subglacial hydrodynamics and associated ice dynamics. A persistent problem for these models is how to accurately parameterize the flow resistance in subglacial conduits. Flow resistance directly regulates the water pressure, energy transfer, and ice-melting in subglacial conduits. Thus, accurate quantification of the flow resistance in real conduits is crucial for better understanding the role of subglacial systems in the hydrological cycle of Greenland ice sheet.

This project is the first attempt to estimate accurate and physics-based flow resistance for a real subglacial conduit. The technologies used include the emerging structure-from-motion photogrammetry and computational fluid dynamics simulations. This project is consisted of three tasks.

Task 1: Recover data in order to map the full conduit at mm resolution.

(1) A 125 m long subglacial conduit under Svalbard, Norway was reconstructed using structure-from-motion. The data has been released to the NSF ArcticData.io repository.

(2) For a 10 m section on this subglacial conduit, two Matlab packages, STL2Conts and Conts2Mesh, were developed to convert structure-from-motion derived surfaces to digital elevation models, to quantify surface roughness, to decompose surface features (surface roughness, cross-sectional changes, and sinuosity) into individual parts, and to prepare geometries for CFD simulations.

(3) One paper was published to understand the roughness in this subglacial conduit in Journal of Glaciology.

Task 2: Use 3D scans of conduit bed roughness to parameterize models of conduit enlargement.

(4) 12 CFD simulations were performed to answer three questions: (a) What is the bulk flow resistance in a realistic subglacial conduit? (b) What is the relative importance of different sources contributing to flow resistance? (c) What are the impacts of our CFD simulated friction factor on predicting subglacial hydrodynamics and ice dynamics?

(5) From our CFD simulations and a 1D simplified subglacial conduit model, we report the following findings: (a) we quantified the bulk flow resistance of a real subglacial conduit as around 2.34. (b) the cross-sectional variations and longitudinal sinuosity in a subglacial are much more important (contributing around 94% of the bulk resistance) than the surface roughness (contributing about 6% of the bulk resistance). (c) most glaciology models may severely underestimate the flow resistance in real subglacial conduits and thus significantly misrepresent subglacial hydrodynamics and ice dynamics.

(6) One paper is currently under review by the journal Geophysical Research Letters.

(7) We also performed 14 simulations to particularly focus on how to properly quantify surface roughness and resulted flow resistance.

(8) Following the same procedure of using structure-from-motion and CFD to quantify flow resistance in complex natural environments, we finished another paper which applies the methods developed in this NSF project to another NSF project.

(9) This project produced a PhD thesis.

Task T3: Simulate the full conduit.

(10) We developed a 1D subglacial conduit model, conduitFOAM, to simulate the hydrodynamics and ice-melting process for subglacial hydrology. A paper is in preparation. This model will be made free in OpenFOAM platform when our paper is published. One paper is being prepared for submission.

Other outcomes include presentations and posters in AGU, CSDMS, and other institutions.

(11) Y. Chen. “Quantifying flow resistance in natural subglacial conduits and mountain streams using computational fluid dynamics and structure-from-motion photogrammetry”. Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL) Seminar, Princeton University. Princeton, NJ, USA, Aug. 2018.

(12) Y. Chen. “Quantifying flow resistance using photogrammetry and CFD in two geophysical settings: subglacial conduits and mountain streams”. Penn State Fluid Dynamics Research Consortium. State College, PA, USA, Feb. 2018.

(13) Y. Chen, X. Liu, and K. D. Mankoff. “conduitFoam: a one-dimensional subglacial conduit mode”. CSDMS Annual Meeting 2018. Boulder, Colorado, USA, May 2018.

(14) Y. Chen, X. Liu, and K. D. Mankoff. “Flow resistance in a real subglacial conduit”. American

Geophysical Union, Fall General Assembly. New Orleans, LA, USA, Dec. 2017.

(15) Y. Chen, X. Liu, and K. D. Mankoff. “Computational modeling of the hydraulics of a realistic

subglacial conduit in Arctic”. CSDMS Annual Meeting 2016. Boulder, Colorado, USA, May 2016.

(16) Y. Chen, X. Liu, K. D. Mankoff, and J. D. Gulley. “Surface features parameterization and equivalent roughness height estimation of a real subglacial conduit in the Arctic”. American Geophysical Union, Fall General Assembly. San Francisco, CA, USA, Dec. 2016.
